ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the dictator novel, prominent Latin American writers, and some historical context for specific cases I haven't been able to study formally in a classroom before.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the class was pretty much perfect as is. It is well organized, we cover a lot, and the professor knows a huge amount about the subject. There were three papers with great topics, and they were not too long, which meant I could spend more time on them and be really happy with what I turned in. I appreciated the feedback as well on the papers. I was really happy for the opportunity to take the class!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Echevarria ran a great class. The one thing is perhaps to boost the speaker on his end; sometimes we found it hard to hear, and had gaps in our notes for these spots when we tried to pool them after class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend! Take a look at the syllabus for the book list, but the Dictator Novel is a really great subject and the Professor Echevarria really is an expert; it is a great privilege to learn from him, and he is very patient with the undergrads. An undergrad can totally take this course and get a huge amount from it. I will say, it is best to take with a friend; we pooled notes afterwards and it really helped us an enormous amount. Also, make a note of the reading; the syllabus says around 100pages of reading per week. It is often far more than that; it is one novel for every two weeks, and the novels ranged from 250 pages to over 500 pages in length, meaning the reading was always more than that. That said, it is totally worthwhile! Several of the books have audiobooks, which I found helped me a lot to listen as I read.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
